facts.text: Assessment year 1960-61, relevant accounting year ending December 31, 1959.
Income-tax Officer issued notice under s. 22(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 on June 1, 1960, served on assessee on June 13, 1960, requiring return by July 18, 1960.
On July 18, 1960, assessee applied for extension of time; Income-tax Officer extended by two months and informed no further time would be allowed.
Assessee failed to furnish return within extended time.
Notice under s. 28(3) of 1922 Act served on assessee on January 16, 1961.
Provisional assessment made under s. 23B of 1922 Act on February 2, 1961; assessee deposited Rs. 92,294/55 P.
Income-tax Act, 1961 came into force on April 1, 1961.
Assessment completed by Income-tax Officer on October 31, 1962; tax due determined at Rs. 1,25,512/10 P.
Penalty proceedings initiated under s. 297(2)(g) of 1961 Act; notice under s. 274(1) served.
Income-tax Officer fixed penalty at Rs. 12,734/10 P. based on tax under s. 143 without deducting provisional payment.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed Income-tax Officer's order.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held penalty under s. 271(1)(a)(i) to be levied on tax assessed minus provisional payment of Rs. 92,294/55 P., fixing penalty at Rs. 2,737/44 P.
Calcutta High Court answered question in affirmative in favour of assessee on June 26, 1969 in Income-tax Reference No. 145 of 1966.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that in calculating the penalty leviable under section 271(1)(a) of the Income-tax Act, 1961 the amount paid by the assessee under the provisional assessment under section 23B of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, was to be deducted from the amount of tax determined under section 23(2) of that Act in order to determine the amount of tax on which the computation of the penalty was to be based and in reducing the amount of the penalty imposed on the assessee to Rs. 2,737/-

petitioner_arguments.text: Penalty to be determined on the basis of the tax assessed under s. 143 of the Act, without deducting amount paid under provisional assessment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 271(1)(a)(i) of Income-tax Act, 1961; Vir Bhan Bansi Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab (Lahore High Court); Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi v. Hindustan Industrial Corporation (Delhi High Court)

respondent_arguments.text: Penalty can only be imposed on the amount payable under s. 156, after deducting prior payments like provisional assessment.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 271(1)(a)(i) and s. 156 of Income-tax Act, 1961; M. M. Annaiah v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore (Mysore High Court)

court_reasoning.text: Expression 'the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him' in s. 271(1)(a)(i) refers to tax payable under demand notice u/s 156 after deducting tax already paid; 'the tax' in penalty computation refers back to that payable tax, not assessed tax under s. 143.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax payable differs from tax assessed; prior payments deducted in determining payable tax.

court_reasoning.text: Language of s. 271(1)(a)(i) capable of more than one interpretation; in taxing/penalty provisions, adopt construction favouring assessee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Calcutta and Mysore High Courts' view preferred over Lahore and Delhi; Revenue's view leads to harsh results.

holdings.text: Penalty under s. 271(1)(a)(i) computed on 'the tax' payable by assessee after deducting payments like provisional assessment under s. 23B of 1922 Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vir Bhan Bansi Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Relied by Revenue (Lahore High Court); Court preferred other view.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi v. Hindustan Industrial Corporation
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Lahore HC view; relied by Revenue (Delhi High Court).

precedents_cited.case_name: M. M. Annaiah v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Supported assessee's view on interpretation of s. 271(1)(a)(i).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisional assessment and notices under old Act; payments deducted for penalty base.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Penalty computation on tax payable under s. 156 after deductions; proceedings initiated under new Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the Commissioner's appeal, affirming Calcutta High Court and Tribunal that penalty under s. 271(1)(a)(i) is computed after deducting Rs. 92,294/55 P. paid under provisional assessment u/s 23B of 1922 Act from assessed tax, reducing penalty to Rs. 2,737/44 P.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal dismissed in favour of assessee

key_quotes.text: 'the amount of the tax, if any, payable by him' ... refers to the tax payable under a demand notice. ... 'the tax' ... can only refer to the tax, if any, payable by the assessee mentioned in the first part of s. 271(1)(a)(i).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation distinguishing assessed tax from payable tax.

key_quotes.text: If two reasonable constructions of a taxing provision are possible that construction which favours the assessee must be adopted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rule of construction applied to resolve ambiguity in penalty provision.

key_quotes.text: A tax payable is, not the same thing as tax assessed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
